affiliation.orgName: RISE-Based Asymptotic Prescribed Performance Tracking Control of Nonlinear Servo Mechanisms
Kunming University of Science and Technology

analytic.title: This article has been accepted for inclusion in a future issue of this journal. Content is final as presented, with the exception of pagination

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: Most function approximator (e.g., neural network or fuzzy system) based control designs can only prove uniform ultimate boundedness of the controlled system due to the unavoidable approximation errors. Moreover, the transient response of conventional adaptive control may be sluggish because high-gain learning is not preferable for guaranteeing system safety. To address these issues, this paper proposes and experimentally validates an alternative robust adaptive control for servo mechanisms with unknown dynamics and bounded disturbances. This control can guarantee asymptotic tracking error convergence in the steady-state, while the transient response can also be prescribed by using an improved prescribed performance function. An echo state network augmented by a smooth friction model is used to accommodate the unknown nonlinearities. The residual approximation error and other bounded disturbances are compensated by using a robust integral of sign of the error term. Comparative experiments based on a practical turntable servo mechanism are conducted to validate the effectiveness of the proposed control scheme and show improved control performance. Index Terms-Adaptive control, echo state networks (ESNs), prescribed performance function (PPF), robust integral of the sign of the error (RISE), servo mechanisms.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: S ERVO mechanisms have been widely used in the practical engineering applications due to their high power density, torque-to-inertia ratio, and efficiency [1]-[4]. However, due to the unknown dynamics (e.g., nonlinear frictions, disturbances, and parameter uncertainties), linear control strategies [e.g., proportional-integral-derivative (PID) control] usually cannot ensure satisfactory performance in the entire operation regimes [5]. In recent years, many researchers have dedicated to develop advanced nonlinear control schemes for servo mechanisms, such as backstepping method [6], robust control [7], [8], adaptive control [1], [9], input-output linearization control [10], and sliding-mode control [11]. In particular, artificial intelligent techniques have also been utilized Manuscript

in the control design to address the unknown nonlinearities (e.g., neural network (NN) [12]- [17] and fuzzy logic system (FLS) [18]- [23]). Among various function approximators, recurrent NNs (RNNs [24]- [29]) and FLS [30]- [32] have been tested in many practical applications. To further reduce the computational costs of RNN and FLS, echo state network (ESN) was proposed in [33] and [34], which can be easily trained without adjusting the weights between the input layer and the hidden layer. However, it is well known that most NN-based control schemes (e.g., [35]) can only guarantee the semiglobal uniform ultimate boundedness of the controlled system because the residual NN aproximation errors cannot be compensated. Thus, the control error in the steady-state converges to a small set around zero only. Moreover, in practical implementation, the training of NNs or FSs may achieve satisfactory performance only after fairly long transient stage. This indicates that the transient response of the controlled system may be sluggish. These two issues limit the application of nonlinear adaptive control schemes in practice.

To address the first issue (e.g., steady-state convergence), sliding mode control (SMC) [36] has been used to eliminate the effect of the NN errors in the control system. These adaptive controllers with SMC suffer from discontinuous control actions, which lead to the chattering problem. Recently, a novel robust integral of the sign of the error (RISE) control was developed in [37] to compensate for bounded uncertainties and disturbances. The key feature of the RISE method is that asymptotic stability can be proved by using an integral of the sign of the error feedback term. Moreover, compared with conventional SMC methods, this scheme generates continuous control signals, and thus avoids the requirement for infinite fast control switchings. This technique was used in [38] for an electrical motor with friction compensation. In [39], a nonlinear control strategy based on RISE was proposed for an autonomous underwater vehicle. Recently, the idea of RISE has also been incorporated into the adaptive NN control for nonlinear systems [40]- [43]. A similar idea was also proposed in [44] following the principle of SMC. However, it is noted that although the RISE control strategies can prove asymptotic convergence in the steady-state, there is no guarantee for the transient convergence performance. In particular, when the online adaptive learning is incorporated into the control design, the potential sluggish response and large overshoot may creates difficulties in the implementation.

In recent years, a new control method based on the prescribed performance function (PPF) that characterizes the convergence rate, maximum overshoot, and steady-error has been proposed in [45] and [46], where both transient and steady-state response can be quantitatively designed and prescribed. The essential merit of the PPF control is that the tracking error of the original system is transformed into a new coordinate system by using a PPF and an associated error transform. To this end, the tracking error of the original system can be retained within a prescribed region when the transformed system can be stabilized via any appropriate controller. The PPF has been successfully extended for various systems [47]- [49]. However, the PPF-based control methods may encounter a potential singularity problem. Moreover, the steady-state control error of conventional PPF control (e.g., [45]- [50]) can only be retained within a small bound, while the asymptotic convergence property cannot be claimed.

In this paper, we will develop a robust adaptive control method for servo mechanisms with unknown dynamics and bounded disturbances. This new control scheme can address both transient response and asymptotic steady-state convergence of the controlled system simultaneously. Thus, the conventional RISE method and PPF scheme can be improved. For this purpose, an improved PPF is incorporated into the control design such that the tracking error can be strictly retained within a prescribed set in the transient stage. To further achieve asymptotic error convergence to zero, a novel smooth robust control term based on the idea of RISE is introduced to compensate for the ESN approximation error and bounded disturbances. Moreover, to compensate for unavoidable friction dynamics in servo mechanisms, a smooth friction model proposed in [51] is adopted to capture various friction dynamics (e.g., Coulomb friction, viscous friction, and Stribeck effects). This friction model is augmented into an ESN, which is used to approximate unknown nonlinearities. Finally, a modified adaptive law is proposed to update the ESN's weight and friction model coefficients online, where the complex projection algorithm [40], [42] can be avoided. It is shown that the use of a continuous friction model and a smooth RISE term can lead to smooth compensation actions because discontinuous control actions are avoided. Moreover, the asymptotic control error convergence can be theoretically proved in comparison to other PPF-based controllers, where the tracking error can only converge to a bounded set in steadystate. Also, the transient response can be prescribed even in the presence of unknown disturbances and ESN approximation errors. Extensive experimental results based on a turntable servo system show that better transient and steadystate performance of the proposed control system are achieved than several other control methods.
The main contributions can be summarized as follows.

1) The idea of RISE is incorporated into the PPF control design, such that the tracking error can converge to zero asymptotically in the steady-state. This improves the standard PPF control designs (e.g., [47], [48], and [52]), where the tracking error only converges to a prescribed set in steady-state. 2) By using the PPF in the RISE-based control design, the transient control response can be prescribed, which also improves the control response of available RISE-based control schemes (e.g., [37] and [38]). 3) A smooth friction model is augmented into an ESN to address the compensation of unmeasured friction dynamics and other unknown dynamics, while a smooth robust term is used to eliminate the approximation error and disturbances. This paper is organized as follows. In Section II, the problem statement and some preliminaries are presented. Section III provides the controller design and the stability analysis. Comparative experiments are given in Section IV. Some conclusions are provided in Section V.

div.head: A. Dynamic Model of Servo mechanisms
div.p: In this paper, we consider the position motion tracking control of a class of nonlinear servo mechanisms, which are driven by a permanent magnet synchronous motor (PMSM). In this system, the inner current control loop was well designed and embedded in the motor drive board, and the objective of this paper is to design a position control to make the angular position track a given reference. The overall schematic diagram of the constructed position control system is given in Fig. 1. Thus, according to [1], the dynamic model of such systems can be described as
div.formula: ⎛ ⎝ id iq q ⎞ ⎠ = ⎛ ⎝ -R L -n p q 0 -n p q -R L n p ψ f L 0 K T J 1 J ⎞ ⎠ ⎛ ⎝ i d i q q ⎞ ⎠ + ⎛ ⎝ u d L u q L -T f -T L -T d -f (q,q) J ⎞ ⎠(1)
div.p: where i d and i q are the d-axis and q-axis stator currents; u d and u q are the d-axis and q-axis stator voltages, respectively; n p is the number of pole pairs, R, L are the stator resistance and stator inductance; T f , T L and T d represent the friction torque, load torque, and disturbance torque, respectively; and f (q, q) denotes the unknown resonances and uncertainties. ψ f is the rotor flux linkage, K T is the torque constant, q, q are the angular position and velocity of PMSM, respectively, and J is the inertia.

In practical systems, the electrical time constant L/R is small in comparison to the mechanical time constant. Thus, the electrical transient Ldi q /dt decays very rapidly to zero. Moreover, in order to eliminate the couplings between the angular speed and current, the d-axis reference current i * d is set to zero [1]. In this case, (1) can be simplified as
div.formula: q = K T JR i q - K T K E JR q - 1 J f (q, q) -T f (q) + d (2
div.p: where K E = n p ψ f , d = (-T L -T d )/J denotes the effect of loads and external disturbances. The model ( 2) has been widely used to describe the dynamics of servo motion control systems. A critical issue in the servo motion control is the compensation of the unknown frictions. For this purpose, many friction models have been developed, e.g., [53] and [54]. However, these widely used friction models are generally discontinuous or piecewise continuous, which may lead to nonsmooth control actions. To address this issue, we will employ a continuous static friction model recently proposed in [51]. Thus, the friction torque T f can be represented as
div.formula: T f = α 1 (tanh(c 1 q) -tanh(c 2 q)) + α 2 tanh(c 3 q) + α 3 q (3)
div.p: where α 1 , α 2 , α 3 , c 1 , c 2 , and c 3 are positive constants.

Compared to other friction models, the model ( 3) is continuously differentiable. We refer to [51] for more detailed explanations on (3). The modeling error of friction dynamics with (3) can be lumped into the disturbances d, and then addressed in the control design.
Assumption 1 [40]: The uncertainties d and its first two time derivatives are bounded such that | ḋ| ≤ δ 1 , | d| ≤ δ 2 hold for positive constants δ 1 and δ 2 .
Assumption 2: The reference trajectory q d and its first two time derivatives qd , qd are bounded. Moreover, the angular position q and speed q are measurable.

The problem to be addressed is to find a continuous control such that: 1) the angular position q can track a given timevarying trajectory q d asymptotically; 2) the transient tracking error e 1 (t) = qq d can be retained within a prescribed bound for all t > 0; and 3) all signals in the closed-loop system are bounded.

div.head: B. Function Approximation Using ESN
div.p: Recently, ESNs have been successfully used to model nonlinear dynamical systems [33], [34] and also used as a state observer to estimate nonlinear function. It divides the weights of RNNs into two parts: 1) a hidden layer (dynamical reservoir) with sparsely and randomly interconnected neurons and 2) a memoryless output layer (readout). The structure of ESNs is shown in Fig. 2, where the ESNs have K inputs, N neurons in the hidden layer, and L neurons in the output layer. ESN can be adopted to approximate any continuous function f (•) : R n -→ R on a sufficiently large compact set ⊂ R n . For arbitrarily small constant ε m , there exists an ESN in the form of (4), such that sup x∈ |f (x)y(x)| ≤ ε m holds for y(x) being the output of ESN. In this sense, the function f (x) can be expressed as where ε * is the approximation error of the ESN and |ε * | ≤ ε m and W * 0 is the ideal value of ESN weights that minimizes the approximation error ε * . Therefore
div.formula: f (x) = W * T 0 X(x) + ε * ∀x ∈ ⊂ R n (4)
W * 0 = arg min W 0 ∈R L×(K+N+L) sup x∈ f (x) -W * T 0 X(x) . (5
div.p: Because the ideal NN weights W * 0 are unknown, we can only use the estimation value Ŵ0 of W * 0 in the control design, which can be online updated via an adaptive law.

Remark 1: Compared with RNN, the ESN can easily be trained without adjusting the weights between the input layer and the hidden layer, and the connection weights of the reservoir network are not altered during the training phase. Thus, the use of ESN can lead to simplified implementation and reduced computational costs. However, it is noted that the ESN can be replaced by other function approximators (e.g., FLS [30]- [32] and NN [13], [25]).

div.head: C. Prescribed Performance Function
div.p: For the position tracking control, we define the tracking error as

Then, to quantitatively study the transient response of the tracking error e 1 (t), we will further extend the principle of the prescribed performance control, which was initially suggested in [45] and [46]. For this purpose, the following positive decreasing smooth function μ(t) : R + → R + will be used as the PPF:
where μ 0 > μ ∞ and k > 0 are positive constants, and it fulfills lim
Then, the transient response of the tracking error e 1 (t) can be guaranteed by the following bound (Fig. 3):

where δ is a positive constant. It is shown in (7) and ( 8) that -δμ(0) and δμ(0) represent the lower bound and upper bound of the undershoot and maximum overshoot, respectively; k introduces the convergence rate and μ ∞ denotes the allowable steady-state error. Thus, the transient response of the control error e 1 (t) can be prescribed by tuning δ, k, μ 0 , and μ ∞ . Following [45] and [46], we will solve the control problem by transforming the PPF condition ( 8) into an equivalent "unconstrained" one. Thus, a transform function ξ(z 1 ) of the transformed error z 1 is used, which has the following properties.
ξ(z 1 ) = δ, and lim
From the properties of ξ(z 1 ), condition (8) equals to
Consequently, the transformed error z 1 can be obtained by calculating the inverse function of ξ(z 1 ) as
Different to [45] and [46], in this paper we propose an improved transform function, which is given as
div.formula: ξ (z 1 ) = δe z 1 -δe -z 1 e z 1 + e -z 1 . (11
div.p: Then, from (10) and (11), the transformed error z 1 can be written as
where λ(t) = e 1 (t)/μ(t).

It is worth noting that for any initial condition e 1 (0), if the designed parameters μ 0 , δ satisfy -δμ(0) < e 1 (0) < δμ(0) and z 1 can be controlled to be bounded, then -δ < ξ(z 1 ) < δ holds, so that the PPF condition -δμ(t) < e 1 (t) < δμ(t) is guaranteed.

Lemma 1 [45], [46]: The system ( 6) is invariant under the transform function (10) with ξ(z 1 ) in (11). Thus, the stabilization of the transform error z 1 in ( 12) is sufficient to guarantee the tracking control of system (2) within the prescribed performance bound (8).
Proof: The proof can be derived based on ( 8)- (10) and the property of function ξ(z 1 ).

Remark 2: Although the idea of PPF initially proposed in [45] and [46] is further extended in this paper, the following control design will be different. In particular, a new RISE-based control will be introduced in this paper, such that the tracking control error e 1 (t) asymptotically converges to zero. However, the steady-state error in [45] and [46] is only proved to converge to a set whose size is defined by μ ∞ .
Remark 3: This paper introduces a modified error transform function in (11) to remedy the potential singularity problem

div.head: III. CONTROLLER DESIGN
div.p: After obtaining the transformed error system (12), the problem to be addressed is to design an appropriate controller such that z 1 is bounded. Essentially different to available PPF-based control strategies, e.g., [45] and [46], we will design a control such that the tracking control error e 1 (t) is not only retained within the PPF bound (8) in the transient stage, but also converges to zero in steady-state. Thus, based on the property of the error transform function (11) and ( 12), the transform error z 1 must be controlled to converge to zero even in the presence of uncertainties, disturbances and ESN errors. For this purpose, we will present a new control strategy by extending the continuous RISE method [42].

The overall control structure can be found in Fig. 4. The control law u includes two parts: ESN adaptive control and RISE. The ESN is employed to compensate the unmeasured friction dynamics and other unknown dynamics, and the RISE is utilized to reject the ESN approximation errors and bounded disturbances.

div.head: A. Derivation of the Filtered Tracking Error
div.p: To facility controller design, we define state variables x = [x 1 , x 2 ] = [q, q] and x d = q d , and define
div.formula: K 1 = K T /R, K 2 = K T K E /R.
div.p: According to the error transform function (12), the following filter errors are defined as:

where k 1 and k 2 are positive constants selected by the designers. It has been noted in [42] that the auxiliary filter error r is not available for the control design because ż2 is not measurable. However, it can provide an alternative method to analyze the system stability and robustness. From ( 12) and ( 13), we have
div.formula: r = z1 + k 1 ż1 + k 2 z 2 = ρ( ẋ1 -ẋd -e 1 μ/μ) + ρ ẋ -ẍd -ė1 μ/μ -ė1 μμ/μ 2 + e 1 μ2 /μ 2 + k 1 ż1 + k 2 z 2 = ρ( ẋ1 -ẋd -e 1 μ/μ) -ρ ẍd + ė1 μ/μ + e 1 μμ/μ 2 -e 1 μ2 /μ 2 + ρ ζ(x) + T f (x 2 )/J + θ u + d + k 1 ż1 + k 2 z 2 = F d (x, ẋd , ẍd , ρ) + ρT f (x 2 )/J + ρθu + k 1 ż1 + k 2 z 2 + ˜ + E(e 1 )(14)
div.p: where
div.formula: θ = K 1 /J is a positive constant. ρ = (1/2μ)[1/(λ + δ) -1/(λ -δ)
div.p: ] can be calculated based on e 1 (t) and μ(t), and fulfills 0
div.formula: < ρ < ρ M for constant ρ M > 0, ζ(x) = (-K 2 x 2 + f (x 1 , x 2
div.p: ))/J, F d (x, ẋd , ẍd , ρ) = ρζ(x) + ρ( ẋ1 -ẋd ) -ρ ẍd are unknown dynamics. ˜ = ρd is the lumped disturbance, and E(e 1 ) = -ρe 1 μ/μ -ρ( ė1 μ/μ + e 1 μμ/μ 2e 1 μ2 /μ 2 ) is the error variable.

In practice, the sensor measurement noise may be unavoidable. Moreover, in most case studies, the angular velocity x 2 is obtained via the backward difference of position signal x 1 and thus is sensitive to the noise signals. Thus, in the following, to eliminate the noise and model uncertainties, we will use the desired trajectory x d , ẋd to replace the measured signals x 1 , x 2 in the ESN approximation, and introduce a new robust term to guarantee the asymptotic convergence. We rewrite (14) as
where the nonlinear function Fd is defined as
div.formula: Fd = F d (x d , ẋd , ẍd , ρ) + ρT f (ẋ d )/J (16
div.p: and the auxiliary function S is defined as
div.formula: S = k 1 ż1 + k 2 z 2 + E(e 1 ) + F d (x, ẋd , ẍd , ρ) -F d (x d , ẋd , ẍd , ρ) + ρ T f (ẋ) -T f (ẋ d ) /J. (17
div.p: To facilitate subsequent stability analysis, the time derivative of r can be given as
Since the friction model (3) and the reference x d are all continuous, the nonlinear function in (18) can be approximated by an ESN as [41]
where W = [W 1 , . . . , W L ] T is the bounded ESN weight vector, (Z) = [ 11 (Z), . . . , 1L (Z)] T ∈ R L is the regressor vector, and ε is a bounded approximation error.
Assumption 3 [42]: The function approximation error ε and its time derivatives are bounded by |ε| ≤ ε b1 , |ε| ≤ ε b2 , and |ε| ≤ ε b3 , where ε b1 , ε b2 , and ε b3 are positive constants.
Substituting ( 19) into (18), the system dynamics in (18) can be written as
div.formula: ṙ = W T (Z) + ρθ u + Ṡ + ˙ + ε. (20
div.p: In the following, an alternative control will be designed to retain the convergence of r and thus z 1 and e 1 .

div.head: B. Controller Design
div.p: In the practical control design, the estimation of Ḟd is used in the control design, which is defined as

where Ŵ is the estimate of the augmented weight W. In the RISE-based control design, the derivative of unknown system dynamics that is also a nonlinear function is approximated by using an ESN. A similar idea has been adopted in [41].
Then based on the system dynamics in (20), the control u is designed as
div.formula: u = 1 ρθ -(k s + 2)z 2 (t) + (k s + 2)z 2 (0) - t 0 ŴT (Z(σ )) + (k s + 2)k 2 z 2 (σ ) + β 1 sgn(z 2 (σ )) dσ = 1 ρθ -μ s - t 0 ŴT (Z(σ ))dσ (22
div.p: where k s is a positive feedback gain, β 1 is a positive constant, sgn(•) is the signum function, and μ s denotes the robust feedback term, which is given as
The ESN weight Ŵ can be updated by using the following adaptive law:

where > 0 is the learning gain matrix, and σ > 0 is the forgetting factor. Note the ESN weights are online updated depending on the tracking error z 2 . In this case, we do not need any offline training phases.
From (22), the derivative of the control law u with zero initial condition is given by
Moreover, one may verify that μs fulfills
Consequently, by substituting ( 26) into (20), one can obtain the closed-loop tracking error system dynamics as
div.formula: ṙ = WT (Z) -(k s + 2)r + β 1 sgn(z 2 ) + Ṡ + ˙ + ε (27)
div.p: where W = W -Ŵ is the weight estimation error.
To facilitate the subsequent closed-loop stability analysis, inspired by [42], we further represent (27) as
div.formula: ṙ = Ñ + N -z 2 -(k s + 1)r + β 1 sgn(z 2 ) (28
div.p: where the unmeasurable auxiliary terms Ñ and N are defined as Similar to the analysis shown in [42], one can apply the mean value theorem on the continuously differentiable function Ñ, and then from ( 13), (19), and (20), it can be verified that Ñ can be upper bounded as follows:
div.formula: Ñ = Ṡ + z 2 -r, N = N B + N d N B = WT (Z), N d = ˙ + ε. (29
div.p: where η is a positive globally invertible nondecreasing function, and z is defined as
Moreover, following the above inequalities, Assumptions 1 and 3, and the analysis in [42], N B , N d and their time derivatives ṄB , Ṅd are bounded by:
div.formula: N B ≤ ζ N B0 , ṄB ≤ ζ N B1 + ζ N B2 z 2 N d ≤ ζ N d1 , Ṅd ≤ ζ N d2 (32
div.p: where
div.formula: ζ N B0 , ζ N B1 , ζ N d1
div.p: , and ζ N d2 are positive constants.

In practical applications, all parameters in the proposed controller should be well tuned. In general, these parameters can be divided into two parts: the prescribed performance parameters μ 0 , μ ∞ , κ, and δ; and the controller parameters k 1 , k 2 , k s , , σ , and β 1 , which are determined based on a trial-anderror method. Here, the tuning guidelines for all parameters are given as follows.

1) Select PPF parameters μ 0 , μ ∞ , k, and δ to satisfy initial conditions -δμ(0) < e(0) < δμ(0). 2) The controller gains k 1 , k 2 , k s , and β 1 should be chosen to tradeoff the tracking precision and the smoothness of the control signals. In general, large k 1 , k 2 , and k s will lead to faster error convergence, whereas the control action may have oscillations. 3) Select appropriately adaptive parameters and σ . In general, a large σ will suppress the parameter adaptation speed. However, since a robust term is used in this paper, the learning gain can be set as a small value, which can eliminate high-frequency oscillations in the control response. Remark 4: In contrary to conventional RISE control, e.g., [42], the transformed variables z 1 , z 2 of tracking error e 1 with PPF are used in the control implementation. Consequently, the transient control constraints (8) of the proposed control can also be strictly guaranteed. Hence, the proposed control can further improve the transient control response in comparison to conventional RISE schemes.

Remark 5: In available PPF methods (e.g., [45] and [46]), where the steady-state tracking error converges to a set whose size is defined by μ ∞ . However, the proposed control in this paper cannot only guarantee that the control error z 1 (e 1 ) is bounded, but also show that z 1 converge asymptotically to zero. In this case, the original tracking error e 1 will converge to zero as well. This can be achieved by using the robust term μ s , which compensates for the effect of ESN error ε and disturbance d. Hence, the control suggested in this paper could enhance the steady-state control performance of PPF schemes.

div.head: IV. STABILITY ANALYSIS
div.p: In order to facilitate the stability analysis of the closed-loop control system, the following Lemma 1 is stated first.
Lemma 2 [37]: An auxiliary function L(t) is defined as
div.formula: L(t) = r N B + N d -β 1 sgn(z 2 ) + Hsgn(z 2 ) + β 2 z 2 2 + z 2 N B (33
div.p: where H = (σ W 2 /4) is an unknown positive constant, β 1 and β 2 introduced in ( 23) and ( 33) are positive constants, which are selected to fulfill the following conditions:
div.formula: β 1 > ζ N B0 + ζ N d1 + 1 k 2 ζ N B1 + ζ N d2 , β 2 > ζ N B2 . (34
div.p: Then the following inequality is satisfied:
Proof: The proof of Lemma 2 can be conducted following the proof of [37, Lemma 1].
The main results of this paper can now be summarized as follows.

Theorem 1: Consider the servo system given by ( 1), the control is given as (22), and the ESN weight is updated via ( 24), then the system is semiglobally stable. Moreover, the tracking error converges to zero asymptotically, i.e., e 1 (t) → 0 as t → ∞, and the transient response of e 1 (t) can be retained within the prescribed performance bound (8).

After completing the squares for the third term in (45), it follows:
where U(y) = c z 2 is a continuous positive semidefinite function over an arbitrary compact set ¯ , which is determined by

Therefore, the inequality ( 46) and ( 38) can be used to show that V L ∈ L ∞ over ¯ , which further implies that z 1 , z 2 , P(t), Q(t), and r(t) ∈ L ∞ . Given e(t), z 1 (t), z 2 (t), and r(t) ∈ L ∞ , the standard linear analysis methods can be used to prove that ż1 , ż2 ∈ L ∞ in ¯ . Since z 1 (t), z 2 (t), and r(t) ∈ L ∞ , the assumption that x d , ẋd and ẍd are bounded can be used to conclude that x 1 , ẋ1 ∈ L ∞ . Given that r(t) ∈ L ∞ in ¯ , it can be used to show that u(t) ∈ L ∞ in ¯ . Hence, we can also verify that ṙ(t) ∈ L ∞ . Since ė(t), ż1 , ż2 , and ṙ(t) ∈ L ∞ , the definitions for U(y) and z(t) can be used to prove U(y) is uniformly continuous in ¯ . In this case, since the transformed error z 1 is bounded, we can recall Lemma 1 and then claim that the tracking control error e 1 (t) can be retained within the prescribed performance bound (8).

In the following, we further prove the asymptotic convergence of the tracking error e 1 to zero. To this end, the definitions of U(y) and y can be used to conclude that ż1 , and ż2 are uniformly continuous, i.e., z 1 , z 2 ∈ L 2 . Thus, according to Barbalat's lemma, we can concluded that where S 0 ⊂ ¯ is a compact set defined as
Moreover, based on the definition for r, one has
Thus, based on the property of the error transform function (12), we can verify that

This implies that the tracking error can converge to zero asymptotically with guaranteed transient convergence bound. This completes the proof. The proof of Theorem 1 is inspired by the work of [42]. However, as we incorporate an improved PPF into the robust controller design, the convergence of the transformed error z i and its relationship with the original tracing error e 1 (t) needs to be considered in this paper.

div.head: A. Experimental Setup
div.p: A turntable servo system driven by a motor is used as the test-rig to validate the suggested control method. The configuration of the whole experimental setup is shown in Fig. 5. This experimental setup consists of a PMSM (HC-UFS13), an encoder and pulse width modulation amplifiers in the motor card (MR-J2S-10A). A digital signal processing board (TMS3202812) is employed as the controller with the sampling time 0.01 s, and a host PC Pentium IV 2.8-GHz PC is used for display. The control algorithms are implemented by Visual C++ program written in CCS3.0 developing environment. In the tests, the angular position is measured by using an encoder with a resolution of 800 divisions, and the quadrature encoder pulse circuit is used for converting the rotation speed and position from the turntable encoder.

div.head: B. Controller Design
div.p: In order to verify the effectiveness of the proposed control scheme, the following four controllers are all implemented and compared in the experiments.

1) ANRISE: This is the control suggested in Section III in this paper, where the RISE compensation (23) and continuous friction model ( 3) are all used. The controller parameters are given as k 1 = 10, k 2 = 1.5, k s = 0.5, and β 1 = 5. The embedded friction parameters in (3) are chosen as c 1 = 0.02, c 2 = 0.01, and c 3 = 0.2. The PPF parameters in (12) are μ 0 = 0.15, μ ∞ = 0.03, k = 0.4, and δ = 1. The learning parameters of ESN are given as L = 6, σ = 0.01, and = 0.5. The control parameters are chosen following the above stated tuning guidelines.
2) ANDSC: This is the adaptive neural dynamic surface controller presented in [55]. The errors are defined as
div.formula: z 1 = x 1 -y d and z 2 = x 2 -s 1 with μ 1 ṡ1 + s 1 = α 1 and α 1 = -k 1 z 1 -θ z 1 T 1 1 /2 -ε1 tanh(z 1 /ω 1 )
div.p: , and the controller is
div.formula: u = -k 2 z 2 -θ z 2 T 2 2 /2 -ε2 tanh(z 2 /ω 2 ) and adaptive laws are θi = i [z 2 i T i i -σ i θi ]/2.
div.p: The controller parameters are k 1 = 9, K 2 = 4, 1 = 2 = 100, μ 1 = 0.01, a1 = a2 = 10, σ 1 = σ a1 = σ a2 = 0.01, and ω 1 = ω 2 = 1. Note in this control, high-order NNs are used, which requests more computational costs than ESN.

3) DCRAC: This is an adaptive robust controller with the Coulomb friction model T f = sgn(x 2 ) as shown in [56]. The adaptive controller is given as [25,0,5, 1000] T , and θ(0) = [0.05, 0.24, 0.1, 0] T . 4) PID: This is the conventional PID controller, which is widely used in industry application. The controller gains are k p = 30, k i = 0.05, and k d = 25, which represent the gains of the proportional, integral, and derivative operations, respectively.
div.formula: u = u a +u s , u a = -ϕ d θ, -ϕ d = [ -ÿd , -ẏ d , -S f (ẏ d ), 1], u s = u s1 + u s2 , u s1 = -k s1 p, u s2 = -(1/4ε)h 2 p, k 1 = 400, k s1 = 32, = diag
div.p: For fair comparison in terms of the robustness and generality of these control methods, all control parameters are determined with a given x d = 0.4 sin(0.4πt) by using a trial-and-error method to make a tradeoff between the steady-state performance and transient response. Then these parameters are fixed and used in all experiments to validate the generality of different controls under wide operation scenarios.

div.head: C. Experimental Results
div.p: To quantitatively compare the tracking responses, the following three performance indices are adopted in this paper to evaluate each control algorithm.
1) Maximum absolute value of the tracking error
where N is the number of the recorded signals.

div.head: 2) Average tracking error
div.p: 3) Standard deviation of the tracking error The aforementioned four controllers are first tested for a slowly varying sinusoid reference trajectory, i.e., x d = 0.4 sin(0.4πt). The tracking profiles and the corresponding tracking errors of the four controllers are depicted in Figs. 6 and7. By comparing the tracking performances of these controllers, it is clear that the proposed ANRISE gives smaller error than other controllers, i.e., it achieves better transient and steady-state error. In particular, although the steady-state tracking performance of ANRISE and DCRAC are comparable to some extent, one can see that the transient response of ANRISE is better than that of DCRAC. This is reasonable because ANRISE includes a PPF to guarantee the prescribed error bound. Nevertheless, the transient and steady-state error of the proposed ANRISE is smaller than ANDSC due to the use of a robust term to enhance the robustness. Moreover, the tedious backstepping procedure in ANDSC is also avoided. All performance indices are summarized in Table I, which also verifies that ANRISE has better tracking performance than PID control, ANDSC, and DCRAC. Moreover, the control action of the proposed method is smoother than other three controllers (Fig. 8). The performances of ANDSC and ANRISE also illustrate that the ESN used in this paper can achieve better estimation performance, which further contributes to the improved control response.

To further validate the efficacy of the proposed control scheme, a sinusoid wave with a larger amplitude, i.e., x d = 0.8 sin(0.4πt) is selected as the reference signal. The tracking errors of the four controllers are depicted in Fig. 9, and the performance indices are given in Table II. It is shown that the proposed control scheme with RISE and PPF can compensate for the model uncertainties and disturbance, and thus improve the transient tracking response in comparison to the other three controllers. From Table II, one may find that although the maximum tracking error M e of ANRISE and DCRAC are most the same, the average error μ e and the standard deviation tracking error σ e of the ANRISE are smaller. Among these controllers, the tracking performance of the conventional PID control method is the worst.
A fast varying reference trajectory x d = 1.0 sin(2πt/3.5) is also tested in the experiment. The experiment results are shown is Fig. 10 and the comparative performance indices are

div.head: TABLE III COMPARISON
div.p: summarized in Table III. From these results, the proposed control scheme can achieve the best tracking performance among the four controllers. In this case, the tracking error responses of PID, ANDSC, and DCRAC have high-frequency oscillations, while the proposed ANRISE still has fairly smooth control response due to the use of the smooth RISE compensation term. Moreover, PID control gives a larger error than others due to the lack of online adaptation. This experimental result validates that the ANRISE has strong robustness against the model uncertainties and disturbance.

Moreover, a sinusoid x d = 1.2 sin(0.36πt) with a larger amplitude 1.2 is used to verify the transient tracking performance. In this case, PID, ANDSC, and DCRAC controllers with those fixed control parameters are difficult to achieve satisfactory trajectory tracking control, and thus their tracking error are not provided. Fig. 11 only provides the control response of the proposed ANRISE, which clearly illustrates that the proposed ANRISE controller can still retain satisfactory tracking performance; in particular, the transient tracking error remains within the prescribed bound.

Finally, a step reference with an amplitude x d = 0.6 is used to further justify the transient performance (e.g., overshoot). To fulfill condition -δμ(0) < e(0) < -δμ(0), the PPF is selected as μ(t) = (1 -0.01)e -3.5t + 0.01 with δ = 1. Comparative results are shown in Fig. 12, from which one can see that the transient performance of the proposed control scheme is better than the other three control methods.

All the aforementioned experimental results clearly show that the proposed ANRISE can guarantee both transient and steady-state performance of the control system. Moreover, compared with other discontinuous friction model, the use of the continuous differentiable friction model together with the ESN could lead to smoother control responses. Moreover, the approximation error of the ESN and friction model as well as other unknown disturbances can be effectively compensated by introducing the RISE term to enhance the robustness.

In order to validate the effectiveness of the proposed RISE term, the generic adaptive controller with original PPF (APC) in [51] is also implemented and compared for the sinusoid signals x d = 0.4 sin(0.4πt). The experiment results of APC and ANRISE are depicted in Fig. 13. From these results, one can find that the tracking error of APC is larger than ANRISE, which validates the efficacy of the introduced RISE term as pointed out in Remark 5.

In the experiments, the system output signals are measured by using encoders, which could subject to measurement noise. Thus, there are small steady-state errors in the experiment results as other RISE methods (e.g., [40]). However, the control errors of the proposed control converge to a very small compact set around zero.

div.head: VI. CONCLUSION
div.p: In this paper, we present and experimentally validate an alternative continuous robust adaptive control method for servo mechanisms. The idea of PPF is further explored and then incorporated into the design of RISE-based control strategy. Thus, asymptotic convergence of the tracking error can be theoretically proved, while the transient performance can be prescribed and strictly guaranteed even in the presence of unknown dynamics and bounded disturbances. This is achieved by using a new smooth RISE compensation term in the PPF control synthesis. Moreover, a continuous friction model is used to address the friction dynamics, and other unknown nonlinear dynamics are approximated by using an ESN. The effect of the ESN reconstruction error and other bounded disturbances are eliminated with the help of a RISE term. Compared with other nonsmooth compensation techniques (e.g., sliding mode term), this continuous robust control can lead to smoother control response and reduced oscillations in the control responses. Extensive experimental results illustrate the effectiveness, the enhanced robustness and better control responses of the proposed control scheme than several other adaptive controllers.

biblStruct.note: Shubo Wang received the B.S. degree in physics from Binzhou University. His current research interests include adaptive control, parameter estimation, neural network, and multidrive servo system
